content: The Act titled "Capital Gains and Dividend Income Reform Act of 1998" introduces a 70-percent capital gains deduction for taxpayers other than corporations, amending Section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act "Capital Gains and Dividend Income Reform Act of 1998" introduces a 70% capital gains deduction for taxpayers other than corporations. This deduction applies to estates and trusts as well, with specific rules for calculating the deduction. Additionally, there is a coordination with the treatment of capital gain under the limitation on investment interest. The transitional rule under section 163(d)(4)(B)(iii) limits the net capital gain taken into account for taxable years including January 1 after the enactment of the Act. This rule applies to gains and losses properly accounted for during that period and reduces the net capital gain for tax purposes. Special rules apply to pass-thru entities. In general, gains and losses for pass-thru entities are determined at the entity level. A pass-thru entity includes regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds. Additionally, a deduction is allowable in computing adjusted gross income under the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow a deduction for long-term capital gains under section 1202. Conforming amendments are made to sections 1, 170(e)(1), 172(d)(2)(B), and 453A(c)(3) of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a deduction for long-term capital gains under section 1202. Amendments are made to various sections of the Code to adjust for this deduction. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to adjust for the deduction under section 1202 for long-term capital gains. Amendments are made to sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding the sale or exchange of capital assets and foreign source capital gain net income. Amendments include changes to Section 904(b)(2)(A) for corporations and Section 904(b)(3) for rate differentials in capital gains. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include adjustments to various sections related to capital gains and tax rates. Section 593(b)(2)(D)(v) and Section 1044(d) are modified, while Section 1211(b)(2) is also amended. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust sections related to capital gains and tax rates. Section 1212(b)(2) is modified to include special rules for determining excess capital gains and losses. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust sections related to capital gains and tax rates. Special rules are introduced for determining excess capital gains and losses in taxable years under section 1211(b). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust sections related to capital gains and tax rates. Special rules are introduced for determining excess capital gains and losses in taxable years under section 1211(b). The amendment includes a transitional rule for capital losses in the first taxable year beginning after December 31, 1998. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust sections related to capital gains and tax rates. Special rules are introduced for determining excess capital gains and losses in taxable years under section 1211(b). Amendments are made to sections 1402(i)(1), 1445(e), and 7518(g)(6)(A) of the Code. Amendments are made to sections 7518(g)(6)(A) and 607(h)(6)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, adjusting tax rates to 15.6 percent (22 percent). Additionally, the item relating to section 1202 in the table of sections for part I of subchapter P of chapter 1 is also amended. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after December 31 of the year including the date of enactment. Amendments related to the repeal of section 1(h) apply to taxable years beginning on or after January 1 following the enactment. Contributions are affected starting January 1 after enactment, and the use of long-term losses applies to taxable years beginning on or after January 1 of the second year after enactment. The amendments made by subsection (c)(12) apply to amounts paid on or after January 1 of the year following the date of enactment of this Act. REDUCTION OF ALTERNATIVE CAPITAL GAIN TAX FOR CORPORATIONS. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to reduce the alternative tax rate for corporations from 35 percent to 22 percent. A transitional rule is also introduced to limit net capital gain for taxable years following the enactment date. Additionally, a special rule for pass-thru entities is included. A conforming amendment is made to adjust the percentage in Section 852(b)(3)(D)(iii). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change the tax rate from 65 percent to 78 percent. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years ending after December 31 of the year of enactment. SEC. 4. 70-PERCENT EXCLUSION OF DIVIDEND INCOME FROM TAX. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a 70-percent exclusion of dividends received by individuals. SEC. 116 introduces a 70-percent exclusion of dividends received by individuals from domestic corporations, with certain exceptions for dividends from tax-exempt corporations. For treatment of capital gain dividends, certain nonresident aliens are ineligible for exclusion unless the dividends are effectively connected with a trade or business in the United States. Dividends from employee stock ownership plans are also excluded from the 70-percent exclusion introduced by SEC. 116. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including coordination with section 116 for common trust fund dividends. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include changes to sections 643, 854(a), and 857(c) regarding the treatment of dividends and coordination with section 116 for partial exclusion of dividends received by individuals. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include changes to the treatment of dividends from real estate investment trusts. These dividends are not considered as dividends for certain tax purposes. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include a 70-percent exclusion of dividends received by individuals. This change will apply to taxable years ending after December 31 of the year that includes the date of enactment of this Act.
